questions.text: In a forensic medicine case review session, a PG resident is discussing the techniques used for age determination in cases involving unidentified remains. A key focus is on the role of ossification centers in estimating developmental stages, particularly in fetal and infant remains. The PG presents a scenario where the remains of a fetus was found, and the determination of the developmental stage is crucial for the ongoing investigation. Based on the standard timeline for the appearance of ossification centers, at what stage of development do the earliest centers of ossification typically appear?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 5-6 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • The earliest centers of ossification are typically visible by 5-6 weeks in utero, marking a significant milestone in embryonic development.
  • The clavicle is the first bone to ossify in the body from two membranous primary ossification centers during the 5–6th postovulatory week.
  • A secondary center forms in the sternal end between 15–17 years and fuses by 20–22 years.
  • In majority of the bones, primary centers of ossification appear between 7th and 12th weeks of intrauterine life. 52 By the age of 11–12th week of IUL, there are 806 centers of ossification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ossification begins as early as 5-6 weeks in utero, providing an early indicator of skeletal development. The clavicle is the first bone to ossify in the body

 

Ref- Reddy 33/e. Pg 83

choices.text: Proof of occurrence of crime

questions.text: A forensic team investigates a scene where a 45-year-old woman was found deceased under mysterious circumstances. The primary task is to establish the foundation for a potential criminal investigation. In this context, the concept of "corpus delicti" is crucial. What does "corpus delicti" specifically refer to in forensic pathology and legal medicine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proof of occurrence of crime

 

Explanation:

 

Corpus delicti (delicti=fault; offence) (the body of offence; the essence of crime)

 

  • The facts of any criminal offence, e.g., murder.
    Ex - The corpus delicti of murder is the fact that a person died from unlawful violence. It includes the body of the victim and other facts which are conclusive of death by foul play, such as a bullet or a broken knife-blade found in the body and responsible for death. Clothing’s showing marks of the weapon, and drawings and photographs of the deceased showing fatal injuries are also included in this term.
  • The main part of corpus delicti is the establishment of identity of the dead body, and infliction of violence in a particular way, at a particular time and place, by the person or persons charged with the crime.
  • The identification of a dead body and proof of corpus delicti is important before a sentence is passed in murder trials, as unclaimed, decomposed bodies, or portions of a dead body, or bones are sometimes produced to support false charges.
  • However, a conviction for an offence does not necessarily depend upon the corpus delicti, if there are eyewitnesses or strong corroborative evidence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Term "corpus delicti" in legal and forensic contexts, highlighting its significance in establishing the occurrence of a crime rather than physical evidence like a body. The literal meaning of term is “the body of offence or the essence of crime”

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 18

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is examining the skull from a set of remains found at an archaeological site. To assist in determining the ethnic background of the individual, which index would be most appropriate for analyzing the proportion and shape of the skull?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cephalic index

 

Explanation:

 

Cephalic Index - The breadth and length are measured by calipers between both parietal eminences, and between glabella and external occipital protuberance, and not by measuring tape.

 

 

Types of skulls:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Nasal index

 

  • Determine race and sex from nasal morphology
  • Formula = nasal width/nasal height ×100.
  • The distance of the widest extension of nose is generally considered as Nasal Width and the Nasal Height is measured from the lower border of nasal bone to the anterior nasal spine, perpendicular to that nasal width.

 

Option C: Crural index - Tibiofemoral Index

 

  • Formula = (Length of Tibia/Length of Femur) × 100
  • For IndiAns. 86.5, Negroes: 86.2, EuropeAns. 83.3.

 

Option D: Brachial index

 

  • Formula = (Length of Radius/Length of Humerus) × 100
  • For EuropeAns. 74.5, Negroes: 78.5

 

Other important index’s –

 

  • Humero-femoral index = (Length of Humerus/Length of Femur) × 100

For EuropeAns. 69, Negroes: 72.4

  • Intermembral index = (Length of Humerus + Radius/Length of Femur + Tibia) × 100

For EuropeAns.> 70, Negroes: < 70.5

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cephalic index, calculated as the ratio of the maximum width to the maximum length of the skull, is crucial in determining the ethnic origin/ race based on skull shape and size.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 58-59

questions.text: During a forensic anthropology workshop, medical students are given a skull for examination. They are informed that the skull is from an individual of Caucasian descent. The instructor asks the students to describe the typical shape of the skull based on anthropological categorization, which would help in identifying the ancestry of skeletal remains. How would the students correctly describe the typical Caucasian skull?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Round

 

Option D:

 

The Caucasian skull is typically characterized as being round or mesaticephalic. This trait is one of the key morphological features used in forensic anthropology to help determine the ancestry of skeletal remains.

 

Note - The skull of an Indian is Mesaticephalic.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Elongated: An elongated skull, or dolichocephalic, is narrower in width and is typically the characteristic of Negroes skulls.

 

Option B: Square: While some skulls may appear square-shaped due to their angular features, this is typically the characteristic of Mongols skulls (Brachyecephalic).

 

Option C: Narrow: A narrow and elongated skull is a feature of Dolico-cephalic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Skull morphology varies significantly among different ancestries: Caucasians typically have rounded skulls, raised foreheads, and straight lower faces; Mongols are characterized by square skulls, inclined foreheads, and large, flattened faces with prominent malar bones; Negroes tend to have narrow, elongated skulls, small and compressed foreheads, and jaws projecting forward with prominent malar bones.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 58-59

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a female infant with developmental delay and short stature. A karyotype analysis is performed, revealing a 45,X chromosomal pattern. The pediatrician explains to the medical students that this finding is consistent with a specific syndrome and that the presence or absence of a Barr body would be a key diagnostic indicator. Which condition associated with this karyotype would not display a Barr body in the patient's cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Turner syndrome

 

Option A:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45, X karyotype, which includes only one X chromosome and no Barr body since there is no second X chromosome to be inactivated. These individuals are anatomically female, pass in external genitalia examination, but have false negative Barr body testing.

 

Barr body

 

  • It is the inactivated X-chromosome, present in female sex.
  • Buccal smear, saliva, hair follicles are used in detection of Barr body. 
  • It is present in 20-80% cells of buccal smear in female and 0 to 4% cells in male.
  • This Barr body is a planoconvex mass lying near nuclear membrane.
  • First demonstrated by “Murray Barr and Edward Bertran” while working on stained sections of nerve cells of Cat

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) includes an extra X chromosome, leads to false positive Barr body testing.

 

Option C: Down’s syndrome is characterized by an extra 21st chromosome and does not impact the formation of a Barr body.

 

Option D: Marfan’s syndrome is an inherited connective tissue disorder, transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait and is not related to the number of X chromosomes or the presence of Barr bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While Turner syndrome (45 XO) does not have a Barr body due to the absence of a second X chromosome, Klinefelter syndrome (47,XXY) includes an extra X chromosome, leads to false positive Barr body testing.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 60

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is teaching medical students about the use of Krogman’s formula in the field of forensic osteology. She explains that this formula is particularly useful when attempting to determine a specific aspect of skeletal remains that is crucial for the identification process in forensic cases. Krogman’s formula is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sex

 

Option C:

 

Krogman's formula is a set of criteria used in forensic anthropology for sex determination from skeletal remains. It is based on the morphological differences between male and female skeletons, particularly the pelvis.

 

Accuracy of sexing based on skeletal remains –

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Race: While certain skeletal features can be used to suggest population affinity, Krogman’s formula is not specifically designed for race determination.

 

Option B: Age: Estimation of age at death from skeletal remains relies on different sets of criteria, such as dental wear or epiphyseal lines.

 

Option D: Stature: Although skeletal measurements are used to estimate stature, Krogman’s formula is specifically utilized for sex determination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Krogman’s formula is used for sex determination of skeletal remains.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 65

questions.text: In a workshop on forensic anthropology, medical students are asked to determine the sex of unidentified skeletal remains most reliably. The remains include a skull, a femur, a pelvis, and a tibia. According to the most widely accepted forensic standards, which bone is considered the most useful for sex determination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pelvis

 

Option C:

 

The pelvis is the most sexually dimorphic bone and provides the most reliable skeletal indicator for sex determination due to differences in morphology between males and females, such as the wider subpubic angle in females.

 

 

 

Obturator foramen

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Skull: While there are sex-specific traits in the skull, it is less reliable than the pelvis for sex determination.

 

Option B: Femur: The femur may exhibit some sexual dimorphism, but it is not as diagnostic as the pelvis.

 

Option D: Tibia: The tibia has less sexual dimorphism compared to the pelvis and is less useful for determining sex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pelvis as the most reliable skeletal element for determining sex in forensic anthropology.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 62

questions.text: A group of medical students is learning about the significance of various skeletal features in determining characteristics of human remains. The instructor points out that the presence of a preauricular sulcus is particularly indicative of one of these characteristics. The preauricular sulcus is useful for the determination of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sex

 

Option B:

 

The preauricular sulcus has been described as a characteristic of the female pelvis. The pelvic portion of the anterior sacroiliac ligament is attached to it. Its prominence results from obstetrical trauma during the course of delivery which allows for differentiation between nulliparous women and males vs females who have given birth.

 

 

Other methods used for Sex determinations are:

 

  • Physical morphology: by External examination
  • Nuclear sexing or sex chromatin or microscopic test: through examination of Buccal epithelial cells or hair follicle cells to detect the presence of ‘Barr body’.
  • Gonadal biopsy: Detection of ‘internal gonads and sex chromosomes’ (genotype sex),
  • Gene-based test: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is used to detect SRY gene (sex-determining region of the Y-chromosome) and/or the DYZ1 region of Y chromosome which is diagnostic.
  • Assay of testosterone levels also helps in differentiating the sex of an individual. For females, they should have levels < 10 nmol/l (lower than the lower limit of normal for male).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Race: The most reliable indicator for race determination are:

 

Skull: Cephalic Index

 

 

  • The indices of long bones may also help in identifying races; e.g. Brachial index (Radio-humeral index), Intermembral index, Humero-femoral index and the Crural index (Tibio-femoral index).

 

Option C: Stature: If the body has been dismembered or skeletonized, the approximate stature may be determined by:

 

  • Length of entire skeleton and 2.5–4 cm for thickness of soft parts.
  • Length from tip of middle finger to the tip of the opposite finger when arms are fully extended.
  • Twice the length of one arm with 30 cm added for two clavicles and 4 cm for sternum.
  • Length from vertex to the symphysis pubis is roughly half of stature.
  • Length from sternal notch to symphysis pubis multiplied by 3.3.

 

Option D: Age: Age determination can be done through many ways. Some are:

 

  • Dental eruption
  • Epiphyseal unions
  • Pubic symphyseal morphology
  • Cranial suture closures
  • Mandibular and sacral changes
  • Miscellaneous - Secondary sexual characters; Age-related degenerative conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sulcus is used for the determination of sex, one of the features to differentiate male and female pelvis.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 62

questions.text: In a practical session on forensic osteology, medical students are presented with a challenge to determine the sex of skeletal remains based solely on cranial morphology. Their professor, an experienced forensic anthropologist, explains that while the skull provides important clues, the accuracy of sex determination based solely on cranial features has a specific rate according to recent studies and forensic standards. Based on these standards, what is the estimated accuracy rate for sex determination using only the skull?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 90%

 

Explanation:

 

The skull provides various morphological clues that can indicate sex, although it's not as definitive as the pelvis. The estimated accuracy is approximately 90%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Krogman, the degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains is:

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 65

questions.text: A medical student observing in the pathology lab notices a hematopathologist evaluating a neutrophil under a microscope. The pathologist points out a small nuclear attachment and explains its significance in determining a specific biological attribute. What does the Davidson body in a neutrophil help to determine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sex

 

Explanation:

 

Davidson body: In females, neutrophil leucocytes contain a small nuclear attachment of drumstick form, named after Prof William Mackay Davidson (1909-1991) a Scottish pathologist, hematologist who first discovered it

 

Females - up to 6% of cells

 

Males - Absent

 

 

Davidson’s body (Peripheral smear)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chromatin positivity in males and females –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 59

questions.text: In a forensic anthropology session, students learn that certain mandibular features can be indicative of sex. The professor displays a skull with a prominent chin shape and asks the students to identify the sex commonly associated with this feature. A square-shaped chin with an everted angle of the mandible is a feature of which sex?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Male sex

 

Explanation:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A square-shaped chin and everted angle of the mandible are characteristic features of a male skull, reflecting the influence of testosterone on bone development.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 62

questions.text: A team of residents in forensic medicine is called upon to assist in a high-profile archaeological discovery. Among the findings is a well-preserved skeleton, which could provide crucial insights into the individual's identity. The lead archaeologist asks the residents to apply Ashley's rule to determine a key aspect of the skeleton's profile. Based on the findings, which attribute can Ashley's rule help to determine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sex

 

Option A:

 

Ashley's rule is a method used in forensic anthropology to help estimate sex from the sternum (skeletal remains)

 

Male: Sternum Body longer and more than twice the length of the manubrium; upper margin is in level with lower part of the body of second thoracic vertebra; breadth more. Length more than 149 mm.

 

Female: Sternum Body is Shorter and less than twice the length of the manubrium; upper margin in level with lower part of the body of third thoracic vertebra; breadth less. Length less than 149 mm.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Age determination typically involves assessment methods like dental wear or bone ossification patterns, which are not addressed by Ashley's rule.

 

Option C: Racial determination often requires a multifactorial approach, including skull measurements and DNA analysis, not just the sternum.

 

Option D: Stature estimation relies on the length of long bones, such as the femur, not the sternum's dimensions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ashley's rule –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 64

questions.text: A group of medical students is participating in an anthropometry workshop. They are presented with a set of pelvic bones and asked to determine which index tends to be higher in males compared to females. Which of the following indices is typically higher in the male pelvis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chilotic line index
 

Option C:

 

Chilotic line: It is an anthropometric line extending from the posterior aspect of the iliopectineal eminence to the closest point on the anterior auricular margin (the pelvic segment) and then to the iliac crest (the sacral portion). Since the pelvic segment is predominant in females and the sacral segment is predominant in males, the chilotic index may be used to identify the sex of human skeletal remains.

 

 

Sacral part of Chilotic line is more in males as compared to females.

 

Males - 120.22 (83-151)     &        Females - 97.58 (72- 161)
 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Ischiopubic index - Public length in mm. x 100/ Ischial length in mm.

 

Males - 73-94 & Females - 93-115
 

Option B: Sciatic notch index - Width of sciatic notch x 100/ Depth of sciatic notch

 

Males - 4-5 & Females - 5 - 6
 

Option D: Sacral index - Transverse diameter of base of sacrum x 100/ Anterior length of sacrum

 

Males - <114 & Females - >114
 

Educational Objective:

 

The sternal index, Sacral index, ischiopubic index and sciatic notch index are more in females. Greater sciatic notch is the ideal feature to determine the sex of a female child.


Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 65

questions.text: During a forensic anthropology class, PG Residents are presented with an intriguing challenge by their professor. They are shown a well-preserved sternum recovered from an archaeological site. The Professor asks the residents to identify the rule that describes the body of the sternum as typically being longer and more than twice the length of the manubrium. This rule is essential in the anthropological evaluation of skeletal remains. Which rule is the Professor referring to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyrtls rule

 

Option C:

 

Hyrtls rule states that the manubrium of the female sternum exceeds half the length of the body, while the body in the male sternum is, at least, twice as long as the manubrium.  This anthropometric measurement can help in identifying skeletal remains.

 

 

Males - 46.2; Females - 54.3

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Puppes rule - lt can determine the sequence of shots when several bullets have struck the cranium. This rule is applicable to any multiple blunt force, causing skull fractures. This rule has been developed by Madea in relation to bullet injuries. The test depends on the observations of the fracture lines either when they intersect each other, or when they intersect a cratered lesion, so that one can determine which crack or defect must have been formed first.

 

Option B: Ashleys rule - Is a method used in forensic anthropology to help estimate sex from the sternum (skeletal remains). According to Ashley's Rule a male sternum typically exceeds 149 mm in length, while a female sternum is generally less than 149 mm

 

 

Option D: Youngs rule - Is calculating the dose of medicine correct for a child. The dose of a drug for a child is obtained by multiplying the adult dose by the age in years and dividing the result by the sum of the child's age plus 12.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Hyrtls law, manubrio corpus index or sternal index exceeds 50 in females and is less than 50 in males or the body is longer and more than the twice the length of the manubrium in males.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 64

questions.text: A forensic expert is giving testimony in a case involving the identification of remains believed to be from an infant. The defense argues that the age of the infant at the time of death is crucial to the case. He refers to standard developmental milestones to support the age estimation, which explains that the emergence of the first deciduous teeth is a key indicator of age in infancy. At what age do the first temporary teeth typically appear in infants?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 months

 

Option A:

 

The eruption of the first temporary tooth is a significant developmental milestone in infancy, typically occurring around 6 months of age. This event is important to monitor as part of the child’s growth and development.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: 12 months - infants usually have 8-12 temporary teeth, at this age.

 

Option C: 18 months - many infants will have around 16 temporary teeth, at this age

 

Option D: 24 months - most children will have most, if not all 20, of their temporary teeth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eruption of deciduous teeth

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 68-69

questions.text: While evaluating a group of juveniles involved in a skateboarding accident, a forensic examiner is tasked with estimating their ages based on skeletal development. One particular case involves determining the age range during which the ossification center at the medial end of the clavicle appears, a key indicator of skeletal maturity. The examiner reviews the X-rays and notes the stage of ossification. At what age does this ossification center typically become radiographically visible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 18 to 19 years

 

Explanation:

 

The appearance of the ossification center at the medial end of the clavicle is a critical marker for age estimation in adolescents. It generally appears between the ages of 18 to 19 years, which can help in age determination in forensic cases or when documentation is lacking.

 

 

A- Appearance and F - Fusion

 

Educational Objective:

 

Age of Ossification –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 73,78

questions.text: In a medical-legal consultation, a forensic expert is reviewing the autopsy findings of skeletal remains suspected to belong to a missing person. The age estimation is pivotal to the identification process, and the expert is focusing on the hyoid bone, which has specific ossification timelines useful for narrowing down the age range. Based on the skeletal assessment, the Expert notes that the greater cornu of the hyoid bone has just begun to fuse with the body. This observation would suggest that the individual was likely within which age range at the time of death?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 40-50 years

 

Explanation:

 

The fusion of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone with the body typically begins later in adulthood, often after the age of 40, and can continue as one ages beyond 50. This makes it a reliable indicator for estimating the age of older adults in forensic cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The greater cornu of the hyoid bone fuses with the body in between 40-50 years

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 79

questions.text: At what age range would the initial ossification center of the pisiform bone most likely be visible on a wrist radiograph?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10-12 years

 

Explanation:

 

Pisiform is a sesamoid bone, the last carpal bone to ossify, attached to flexor carpi ulnaris and appearance of ossification center at 9-12 years of age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Typical age range for the appearance of the ossification center of the pisiform bone on wrist radiograph is 9-12 years.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 82

questions.text: A forensic medicine resident is studying a collection of skulls to learn how to estimate various biological characteristics from skeletal remains. One of the skulls displays a notably higher position of the mental foramen. The resident recalls that this anatomical feature can provide important clues in forensic assessments. What aspect of an individual's profile can be estimated by observing the relative position of the mental foramen on the mandible?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Age estimation.

 

Option B:

 

The relative position of the mental foramen on the mandible can be a useful indicator of age. As a person ages, the foramen typically moves superiorly due to the resorption of the mandible. This characteristic can be helpful in the age estimation of skeletal remains.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Sexual differentiation would not be accurately determined by the position of the mental foramen.

 

Option C: Racial differentiation is typically assessed through a combination of cranial measurements and features, and while the mental foramen may contribute to this assessment, it is not solely indicative of racial background.

 

Option D: The manner of death is unlikely to be determined by the position of the mental foramen, as this does not correlate with cause or manner of death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mandible at various stages –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 79

questions.text: A forensic researcher is presented with skeletal remains for analysis. Part of the assessment includes determining the age of the deceased at the time of death to help with identification. The researcher notes that the sacral vertebrae are fused, which is a key indicator in the age estimation process. In skeletal analysis, fusion of the sacral vertebrae into a single bone is expected to occur within which age range, providing valuable information for age determination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 21 to 25 years

 

Explanation:

 

The fusion of sacral vertebrae is considered a significant indicator of age. The five sacral vertebrae remain separated by cartilage until puberty, and with the onset of puberty, ossification of intervertebral discs starts from below upwards and fusion becomes complete by 20–25 years. A gap may persist between Sl and S2, until 32 years due to "lapsed union"

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sacral vertebrae fusion as an indicator to estimate the age of skeletal remains, which is typically completed between the ages of 20 to 25 years.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 80

questions.text: Shovel-shaped incisors are a dental feature that can be used in forensic anthropology to help determine racial origins. This trait is most commonly associated with which population group?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mongoloids

 

Option B:

 

Race:

 

  • ‘Shovel-shaped’ upper central incisors can be found in most Mongoloids and Americans. In white races, lateral incisor in upper jaw is smaller than the central, especially in females.
  • Carabelli’s cusp (seen in whites), taurodontism (bull tooth) and enamel pearls (common in Mongoloids) have been listed as racial determinants.
  • Taurodontism, especially in maxillary molars, enamel pearls on premolars and congenital lack of upper 3rd molars are commonly seen in Mongoloids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Negroid - The teeth are small with spacing, especially with midline diastema. There is an increased tendency for the existence of supernumerary teeth. The lower first premolar has two distinct cusps; sometimes even three cusps.

 

Option C: Caucasoids - Caucasoids usually have narrow “v-” shaped arch giving rise to crowding of teeth. The anterior teeth of Caucasoids are described as “chisel shaped” having smaller and smoother lingual surface.

 

Option D: Europeans. Europeans, generally classified under the Caucasoid racial group, typically do not exhibit shovel-shaped incisors as a common dental trait.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Mongoloids upper incisors are shovel-shaped, canine roots are long and pointed, enamel pearls are frequent, pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep and the roots are fused and bent; a congenital lack of third upper molar is most common in Mongoloids, but can occur in any race. In Negroids teeth are large with more cusps in their molars with two lingual cusps on mandibular first premolars

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 100

questions.text: A forensic medicine resident is investigating a crime scene where a suspect left fingerprints on a glass surface. During the processing of the scene, the resident must correctly identify the type of fingerprint in order to use the appropriate technique for collection and analysis. What is the term used to describe a fingerprint that is left on a smooth surface like glass and is not immediately visible to the naked eye?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Latent print

 

Option A:

 

A latent print or Chance print is a fingerprint that is not visible to the naked eye and requires additional processing to be seen. These prints are left by the natural oils and sweat on the skin and can be made visible through dusting with powders or the use of chemical reagents. Processing latent prints to render them visible and suitable for comparison is called development, enhancement, or visualization.

 

Latent prints are the most prominent example of Locard’s Principle of Exchange: ‘when two objects come into contact with each other, there is always some transfer of material from one to the other’; hence, the great importance of visualizing them onto useful evidence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Visible prints, also known as patent prints, are fingerprint impressions that are visible without any enhancement, such as a bloody fingerprint left on a light-colored surface. It is often made from grease, dark oil, dirt, or blood, rendering it visible and recognizable, and even suitable for comparison without additional processing.

 

Option C: Plastic prints - (impression/indentation print) is a three-dimensional impression left in a soft material such as wax, soap, butter, tar, paint or putty. Such prints have a distinct character, immediately recognizable and require no further processing.

 

Option D: Delta print is not a recognized term in fingerprint analysis. The delta refers to a triangular area found in fingerprint patterns.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A latent print or Chance print is a fingerprint that is not visible to the naked eye and requires additional processing to be seen; Visible/ patent prints are fingerprint impressions that are visible without any enhancement, such as a bloody fingerprint left on a light-colored surface; Plastic prints (impression/ indentation print) is a three-dimensional impression left in a soft material.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 86-87

questions.text: During a forensic odontology seminar, a case is presented involving the identification of a victim from a mass disaster. Dental records are incomplete, so the forensic team turns to palatal rugae, also known as palato prints, which are unique to each individual and resist postmortem changes. The residents are asked to identify from which part of the palate these prints should be obtained for the most reliable comparison. From which part of the palate are palato prints, used for human identification, typically taken?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior part.

 

Option A:

 

  • Palatoscopy/Palato-Print/Rugoscopy: It is the study of palatal rugae in order to establish identity.
  • Rugae (‘plica palatine’) are anatomical fold or wrinkles formed 12-14th week of IU life.
  • This irregular fibrous connective tissue is located on the anterior third of the palate, behind the incisive papilla.
  • Palatine rugae are unique and can be used for identification in circumstances when it is difficult to identify a dead person through dental records or fingerprints (even in advanced decomposition).
  • This method of identification is useful, if antemortem record of palatal rugae is available.

 

This method is useful since:

 

  • Rugae pattern remain stable throughout life and does not change during growth.
  • It is protected from trauma due to its situation and from heat by buccal pad of fat and tongue.
  • Even in twins, the pattern of rugae may be similar but not identical

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: The posterior part of the palate does not provide as distinctive rugae patterns and is less commonly used for identification.

 

Option C: The lateral part of the palate also does not have the distinct rugae patterns necessary for reliable identification.

 

Option D: The central part of the palate is not as prominent in rugae patterns and is therefore not the preferred area for palato print identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Palatoprints - In the anterior part of the palate, the structural details like the rugae are individual specific and permanent. The palatoprints can be used in the same way as fingerprints.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 88

questions.text: During a forensic anthropology rotation, a medical resident is tasked with estimating the age of unidentified skeletal remains. The resident recalls that certain bones are more reliable for age estimation during specific decades of life and selects the most appropriate bone to examine for an individual who is believed to have been in their third to fifth decade of life. Which bone is considered the most reliable for estimating the age of an individual between the third and fifth decade of life?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pubic symphysis.

 

Option C:

 

The pubic symphysis is a joint that undergoes predictable changes in surface morphology throughout adulthood. This surface undergoes a regular progressive change from 18 years onwards. It is the best single criterion for determining age-at death for individuals from third to fifth decade. Features that are noted on the symphyseal surface are ridges and furrows, dorsal margin, ventral beveling, lower extremity, ossific nodule, upper extremity, ventral rampart, dorsal plateau and symphyseal rim.

 

Age determination from pubic symphysis (in males)

 

 

Note: If male criteria are used for females, the age would be underestimated by about 10 years.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Sacrum - Is not the most reliable bone for age estimation within this age range, as the five sacral vertebrae remain separated by cartilage until puberty, and with the onset of puberty, ossification of intervertebral discs starts from below upwards, and fusion becomes complete by 20–25 years.

 

Option B: Skull - Age estimation from skull is usually done by examination of sutures but is less specific than the pubic symphysis for individuals in the third to fifth decades of life.

 

Option D: The mandible undergoes various changes throughout life but does not have as clear and consistent markers for age estimation in the third to fifth decades.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pubic symphysis is the most reliable skeletal site for estimating the age of adults in the third to fifth decade of life based on the morphological changes of the symphyseal face.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 76-77

questions.text: A resident in forensic pathology is examining skeletal remains that were recently discovered in a coastal area. One of the aspects of the skeletal assessment includes the sternum, where the fusion of the manubrium to the sternal body can provide a clue to the age of the individual at the time of death. At approximately what age does the manubrium typically fuse with the body of the sternum, an observation which can aid in estimating the age of skeletal remains?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60 to 70 years.

 

Explanation:

 

The manubrium, the upper part of the sternum, generally fuses with the body of the sternum between the ages of 60 and 70 (Manubriosternal joint/ Sternal angle/ Angle of Louis). This is a normal part of the skeletal maturation process and can be used as an indicator of age.

 

The age of union of xiphisternum with sternum body - 40-45 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Age of Ossification –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 79

questions.text: A resident in orthopedic surgery is reviewing pelvic radiographs of patients of various ages to learn about developmental milestones of the hip bones. A particular focus is placed on the triradiate cartilage, which is essential for the growth of the acetabulum and overall hip development. At approximately what age is the triradiate cartilage typically obliterated, as seen on a pelvic radiograph, signaling the end of acetabular growth?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 13 to 15 years

 

Explanation:

 

The triradiate cartilage, which is found where the ilium, ischium, and pubis meet to form the acetabulum, typically fuses, or becomes obliterated between the ages of 13 and 15. This event coincides with the end of the growth period of the hip bones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Appearance of ossification centers in Hip bone (in males) -

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 82

questions.text: When evaluating bone development in children, certain joints can provide critical insights into their age. In a clinical setting where age estimation is necessary for a child body between 2 to 6 years, which joint would be the primary focus?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wrist joint.

 

Option A:

 

Ossification of the carpal bones occurs in a predictable sequence, starting with the capitate and ending with the pisiform. At birth, there is no calcification in the carpal bones. Capitate and hamate ossify during infancy (1 year), the former preceding the later. Between 2-6 years, the number of carpal bones present on X-ray wrist represents the approximate age in years, e.g. 3 carpal bones-3 years.

 

Approximate ossification times are –

 

  • Capitate: 2nd month
  • Hamate:  3-4 months
  • Triquetral: 3 years
  • Lunate: 4 years
  • Scaphoid: 5 years
  • Trapezium: 6 years
  • Trapezoid: 6-7 years
  • Pisiform: 9-12 years

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Shoulder joint –

 

  • At 5–6 years, the three (Head, Greater tubercle and Lesser tubercle) fuses together (conjoint epiphysis) and at 17–18 years, fuses with the shaft.

 

Option C: Elbow joint –

 

  • Humerus - At 14–15 years, Capitulum, Trochlea and Lateral epicondyle fuses with the shaft; & at 16 years medial epicondyle fuses with the shaft.
  • Radius and Ulna - upper end fuses at 15-17 year

 

Option D: Ankle joint –

 

  • Tibia and Fibula - Lower end fuses at 16-17 year
  • Talus and Calcaneum - fuses at 17-18 year

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wrist joint is the key anatomical site for the estimation of age in children between 2 to 6 years old, utilizing the appearance and fusion of multiple ossification centers.

 

NOTE - X-rays of elbow, wrist, clavicle, and shoulder joints (upper extremity) and hip, knee, and ankle joints (lower extremity) are usually recommended to determine the age before 25 years of age. If all the epiphyses of all the long bones are united, the person is most probably over 25 years of age.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 72, 80

questions.text: Dental maturity is an important metric for age estimation in forensic examinations. Considering the eruption patterns of teeth, at what age does the first permanent tooth normally erupt in the oral cavity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 67 years

 

Explanation:

 

The first permanent tooth in the oral cavity to erupt is typically the first permanent molar, which usually erupts around the age of 6 to 7 years. This tooth is key in dental age estimation because its presence signifies the transition from primary to permanent dentition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eruption of Permanent teeth

 

 

Mnemonic: Mother Is In Pain Papa Can Make Medicine

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 71

questions.text: A forensic anthropologist is examining the remains of a young individual discovered at an archaeological site. To assist in determining the age of the individual at the time of death, the anthropologist is carefully analyzing the dentition, which can provide valuable clues regarding the developmental stage. In the examination of skeletal remains, what combination of permanent and temporary teeth would likely be present in the jaw of a deceased individual estimated to be around nine years of age?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 16 permanent and 8 temporary

 

Explanation:

 

Period of mixed dentition: Starting from day of eruption of first permanent molar till before the eruption of last permanent canine-both temporary and permanent teeth are present in the jaw. This duration is known as period of mixed dentition. Usually, it is between 6-11 years, but may persist until 12-13 years. From 6-11 years, the number remains 24 because as and when a tooth erupts, it displaces another and the number remains constant.

 

During the period of mixed dentition the number of permanent teeth = (age - 5) x 4.

 

So for 9 years, it is = (9 - 5) × 4 = 16 permanent.

 

Total number of teeth during the period of mixed dentition is 24.

 

Hence, number of temporary teeth = 24 - 16 = 8

 

Note - There is addition of teeth from the age of 12–14 years, when the second molar erupts and the total number becomes 28. Then, the number remains constant till 17 years and again 4 more teeth are added from 17–25 years and the number become 32.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The period of mixed dentition is between the age of 6-11 years.

 

Number of teeth with age –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 70-71

questions.text: During a seminar on forensic odontology, dental students are learning about the FDI World Dental Federation notation, a universally accepted method for dental charting. The instructor provides a scenario where the students must identify the notation for the first permanent molar in the right upper quadrant of the mouth. In the FDI dental charting system, which number corresponds to the first permanent molar located in the right upper quadrant?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 16

 

Explanation:

 

According to the FDI World Dental Federation notation, the first permanent molar in the right upper quadrant is denoted by the number 16. The first digit '1' indicates the quadrant (upper right), and the second digit '6' indicates the first molar.

 

FDI (Federation Dentaire International) - two-digit system: A two-digit notation capable of indicating tooth and quadrant was developed. Thus, lower right canine will be numbered 43. This was adopted as the International Standard.
 

 

Modified FDI system: In this method, the tooth and quadrant are designated by a separate number. Right quadrant was designated aby 2 and 3, and left was designated by 1 and 4 in permanent teeth.

 

Other important charting methods –

 

 

3. Haderup system: It is similar to Palmer notation, except it uses a plus sign (+) to designate upper teeth and a minus sign (-) for lower. For the deciduous teeth, a zero was additionally placed in front of the number

 

 

4. Diagrammatic or anatomical chart: In this, each tooth is represented by a pictorial symbol that gives the same number of tooth surfaces as those on that particular tooth in mouth. Incisors and canines are represented by four surfaces, premolars and molars by five.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FDI World Dental Federation notation system, particularly the numbering of the first permanent molar in the right upper quadrant as number 16.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 99-100

choices.text: Keep reference scale above the wound and take the photo by keeping the camera on the same plane of the wound.
Use a two-swab technique for saliva collection.
Provide a complete description of the injury as seen.
Make a mold using vinyl polysiloxan.

questions.text: A forensic examiner is documenting injuries on a victim of an assault. Among the findings is a clear bite mark on the victim's arm. The examiner prepares to collect evidence from the bite mark following standard forensic procedures. In the forensic analysis of bite marks, which of the following procedures is NOT appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Keep reference scale above the wound and take the photo by keeping the camera on same plane of the wound.

 

Option A:

 

Bite mark investigation:

 

  • Photographic Documentation: Bite marks are photographed with two scales at right angles in the horizontal plane to minimize distortion.
  • Saliva Swabbing: A cotton swab moistened with saline collects saliva for DNA analysis and to determine the secretor status of the assailant.
  • Impression Making: Materials like silicone or plaster create a permanent negative cast of the bite mark for detailed examination.
  • Digital Imaging: Bite marks are digitally rendered into 3D datasets for precise measurement and comparison with the dentition of potential suspects.
  • Tissue Preservation: During an autopsy, the skin with the bite mark can be excised and preserved in formalin for further analysis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: A two-swab technique for saliva collection is a standard procedure in forensic evidence collection from bite marks to obtain potential DNA evidence.

 

Option C: Providing a complete description of the injury as seen is a fundamental aspect of forensic documentation for legal and investigative purposes.

 

Option D: Making a mold using vinyl polysiloxan is an acceptable practice for obtaining a three-dimensional representation of the bite mark for further analysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bite mark is fully photographed with two scales at right angle to one another in the horizontal plane. Photographs of the teeth are taken by using special mirrors which allow the inclusion of all the teeth in the upper or lower jaws in one photograph.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 99

questions.text: A forensic medicine resident is attending a workshop on dermatoglyphics, the study of the pattern of epidermal ridges on the fingers and palms. As part of a practical exercise, the resident is analyzing fingerprint samples from a cross-section of the population to understand the distribution of different types of fingerprint patterns. In a population study of fingerprint patterns, which type is most found among individuals?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loop.

 

Option A:

 

The loop pattern is the most prevalent fingerprint pattern in the general population. This type of pattern is characterized by ridges that enter on one side of the finger, form a curve, and then exit on the same side. Loops are subdivided into radial and ulnar loops, depending on the direction of their opening. This pattern is significant in forensic science due to its high occurrence rate, which can be a critical factor in the identification process.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Whorl patterns, identifiable by their circular or spiral formation, are the second most common type but are less prevalent than loops.

 

Option C: Arches are the simplest and third most common fingerprint patterns, with ridges flowing in one side and out the other without recurving.

 

Option D: Composite patterns are complex and incorporate characteristics of two or more of the basic patterns (loops, whorls, and arches), making them least common.

 

Some Important Pointers

  • Dactylography (dermatoglyphics, Galton system) is the study of fingerprints as a method of identification.

  • A fingerprint match is widely accepted as most reliable evidence of identification.

  • This system was first used by Sir William Herschel in 1858.

  • Sir Francis Galton systematized this method in 1892.

  • There are four basic ridge patterns as given below

 

 

Mnemonic: Love Wife And Children

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dactylography (dermatoglyphics, Galton system) is the study of fingerprints as a method of identification.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 85

questions.text: A forensic investigator is giving a lecture to medical students about various identification methods used in forensic science. One of the topics discussed is cheiloscopy, an area of investigation that has gained significant attention for its unique application. Cheiloscopy is the study and analysis of which specific type of prints?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lip prints.

 

Option A:

 

  • Cheiloscopy is the scientific study of lip prints. Lip prints, like fingerprints, are unique to each individual and can be used for identification purposes.
  • Lip prints are revealed at the point of direct, physical contact of the individual’s lips with an object at the scene of crime, e.g. cutlery and crockery items, particularly if a meal was eaten, or on the surface of windows, plastic bags and cigarette ends.
  • Techniques used in fingerprinting are useful for this purpose—easiest method makes use of fingerprint powders and fixing on foil. Aquaprint and cyanoacrylamide may be also applied.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Nose prints are more relevant in the study of animals, especially in veterinary forensics.

 

Option C: Palate prints, or palatoscopy, involve the study of the lines and ridges on the roof of the mouth.

 

Option D: Tongue prints, while unique to individuals, are less commonly used in forensic investigations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cheiloscopy is the study of lip prints

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 88

questions.text: In forensic analysis, at what stage of intrauterine development are a fetus's fingerprint patterns fully formed, a key detail that can assist in determining the gestational age?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 24th week

 

Explanation:

 

Dermal carvings or ridges appear first time from the 12th-16th week of IUL and their formation gets completed by 24th week, i.e. 6th month IUL, and remain constant throughout embryonic life, birth and the life of the individual.

 

  • Fingerprints do not change throughout life, unless damage has occurred to the dermal skin layer.
  • Temporary loss of fingerprints may be seen when there is swelling of the fingers, e.g. when stung by bee, but returns when the swelling recedes.
  • Permanent impairment of fingerprint pattern also occurs in leprosy, electric injury and after exposure to radiation (injury should involve 1–2 mm beneath the skin surface).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Full establishment of fingerprint patterns occurs by the 24th week of fetal development

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 85

questions.text: In a class on the history of forensic science, students are learning about the evolution of identification methods used in criminal investigations. The professor discusses Alphonse Bertillon, a pioneer in forensic science, and the system he developed in the late 19th century, which marked a significant advancement in the field at that time. The Bertillon system, an early method of criminal identification, was instrumental in the development of forensic science. What fundamental aspect did this system utilize for identifying individuals?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthropometry.

 

Option B:

 

The first scientific method of criminal identification, called bertillion system, is attributable to Alphonse Bertillon, includes- descriptive data, body marks, photographs, and body measurements such as head length, width, arm length, and other body dimensions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Fingerprint - Dactylography (dermatoglyphics, Galton system) is the study of fingerprints as a method of identification. A fingerprint match is widely accepted as most reliable evidence of identification. This system was first used by Sir William Herschel in 1858. Sir Francis Galton systematized this method in 1892.

 

Option C: Lip print - Cheiloscopy is the scientific study of lip prints. Lip prints, like fingerprints, are unique to each individual and can be used for identification purposes.

 

Option D: Nose print - Nose prints are more relevant in the study of animals, especially in veterinary forensics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bertillon system in the field of forensic science, which was based on anthropometry, the measurement of physical characteristics of the body, as a means of early forensic identification.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 85

questions.text: During a training session on forensic odontology, a group of medical residents is introduced to various methods used for age estimation in children. The instructor presents a case study where the age of a child was determined through an analysis of the child's teeth, focusing on a specific method that utilizes the height and weight of teeth.  Which method employs the height and weight of teeth as key parameters for calculating a child's age?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stack's method.

 

Option A:

 

Stack’s method: Stack evolved a method to estimate the age from the weight of the erupting teeth of fetus and infant. He provided a regression line of weight of growing dental tissues against age (from 5 months in utero to postnatal age of 7 months)

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Boyde's method: This method, applicable mainly to estimate age of dead infants, is based on counting the number of cross striations in the enamel of teeth (incremental lines) from neonatal line onwards.

 

Ameloblasts produce enamel at a rate of 4 U/ day. The new enamel formed each day appears as distinct line called incremental line in histology sections. The darkest incremental line is formed at birth due to stress of being born. This is called neonatal line. Counting the incremental lines in enamel outside the neonatal line can reveal the post-natal age. Counting lines prior to neonatal line will give prenatal age.

 

Option C: Gustafson's method - Age estimation consists of microscopic examination of longitudinal section of central part of the tooth to assess changes in teeth as a result of wear and tear with advancing age. Is for estimation of age after 25 years. Useful only while examining dead body or skeletal remains, as teeth need to be extracted for examination.

 

Option D: Pearson's method - Pearson’s regression formula is used determine the stature based on long bones (first reported this in 1899). When whole skeleton is not available, but one or the other long bones are available, then regression equations are used.

The formula for femur being: Stature = 81.306 + 1.88 × F (length of femur in males)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stack's method in forensic odontology for estimating the age of children based on the measurement of height and weight of their teeth. Boyde's method estimates the age of deceased infants by counting enamel cross striations. Gustafson’s method assesses age-related changes in teeth through microscopic examination. Pearson's method calculates stature from long bones.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 72

questions.text: A forensic dentist is conducting a training session with medical residents on age estimation techniques in forensic odontology. As part of the session, the dentist presents various dental attributes and their significance in Gustafson's method. The residents are asked to identify the most reliable dental attribute for estimating the age of an individual in forensic examinations. In utilizing Gustafson's method for dental age estimation in forensic cases, which dental characteristic is considered the most dependable indicator of an individual's age?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Root transparency

 

Option D:

 

In Gustafson's method, root transparency is the most reliable criterion for estimating an individual's age. This characteristic becomes more pronounced with advancing age due to the continuous deposition of secondary dentin, making the roots appear more transparent. This attribute's progressive nature with age makes it a key indicator in forensic dentistry for age estimation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Root resorption - Involves both cementum and dentin. Starts at apex and extends upwards. This can be influenced by various factors, not just age, and hence is less reliable.

 

Option B: The deposition of secondary dentin is Progressive infilling of the dental pulp cavity, decreases the size of cavity and may completely obliterate it. 

 

Option C: Cementum apposition - Cementum increase in thickness around the root due to changes in tooth position, continuously deposited throughout life and forms incremental lines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gustafson’s most reliable criteria - Root transparency - Occurs in root from below upwards in lower jaw and above downwards in upper jaw due to rarefaction of the dentin tissue. Most reliable of all criteria

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 70

questions.text: A forensic expert is conducting an age estimation study using Gustafson's method on a set of skeletal remains. Considering the method's reliance on specific dental changes, which tooth type is most appropriate for this analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Incisors

 

Explanation:

 

Anterior teeth are more suitable than posterior teeth. Merit decreases from incisors to premolars; molars are quite unsuitable. 

 

Gustafson's method assesses attrition, secondary dentin deposition, and changes in cementum and root transparency.

 

Educational objective:

 

Incisors are the most suitable teeth for age estimation using Gustafson's method. Merit decreases from incisors to premolars; molars are quite unsuitable.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 70

questions.text: A forensic medical team is examining the remains of a fetus found in a water body. The fetus measures 35 cm in length, weighs 1050 grams, and has testes located at the external inguinal ring. To assist in the investigation, the team needs to estimate the gestational age of the fetus. What is the most likely age?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 28 weeks

 

Explanation

 

Fetus features at 28 weeks:

 

Length: 35 cm, weight: 900–1200 g, crown-rump: 23–25 cm, foot length: 5.4 cm.

 

Eyelids are open, pupillary membrane disappears; nails are thick, but do not extend to the tips of fingers and toes; skin is dusky-red, thick, and fibrous; meconium present in entire large intestine.

 

Center of ossification for talus appears.

 

These measurements are critical for determining the gestational age of a fetus in cases of unexpected fetal death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Determination of age of fetus

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 83-84

questions.text: A group of medical students specializing in forensic medicine is attending a lecture on dactyloscopy, the study of fingerprints. The lecturer, a forensic expert, is discussing the fundamental principles of fingerprint analysis. One critical topic is the rule that underscores the uniqueness of fingerprints in every individual. In the context of fingerprint analysis, which rule asserts that no two individuals share the same fingerprint pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Quetlet's rule.

 

Option D:

 

Quetlet's rule states that no two individuals have identical fingerprint patterns. This principle is crucial in forensic fingerprint analysis and is foundational for the use of fingerprints in personal identification. It underlines the uniqueness of fingerprint patterns, making them a reliable and widely accepted method for individual identification in forensic investigations.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Nysten's law is related to PM changes. Rigor mortis affects first the muscles of jaw, followed by those of the face and neck, then muscles of the trunk and arms, and lastly the legs and feet.

 

Option B: Shapiro rule - Shapiro (1950) suggests that rigor mortis does not follow the anatomical sequence usually described. He suggests that as rigor mortis is a physicochemical process, it is most likely to develop simultaneously in all the muscles, although the changes are more easily first detected in the smaller masses than in the larger.

 

Option C: Young's rule - The dose of a drug for a child is obtained by multiplying the adult dose by the age in years and dividing the result by the sum of the child's age plus 12:

 

Educational Objective:

 

Quetlet's rule establishes the uniqueness of fingerprint patterns, it states that no two individuals have identical fingerprint patterns

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 86

questions.text: A researcher is presenting a seminar on tooth development and variations. The focus is on the concept of categorization of teeth. Which type of teeth falls into the category of 'super-added' permanent teeth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Molar

 

Option D:

 

Developmentally teeth are divided into 2 sets:

 

A. Super-added permanent teeth: These teeth do not have deciduous predecessors. All permanent molars belong to this category (6 in each jaw).

 

b. Successional permanent teeth: These teeth erupt in place of deciduous teeth, e.g. permanent premolars erupt in place of deciduous molars (10 in each jaw).

 

Some important Pointers –

 

  • Usually, permanent teeth erupt first in lower jaw.
  • Permanent teeth appear few months earlier in girls than in boys.
  • Eruption of teeth is useful in estimating age up to 15 years. The third molar (wisdom tooth) erupts after this time but is so variable in eruption that it is not a reliable age indicator.
  • The mandibular third molar is the most commonly impacted tooth in the mouth and is closely followed by maxillary third molar, maxillary canine, and mandibular canine respectively.
  • If, in the jaw all 3rd molars are present, then the age is over 18 years, but their absence gives no certain idea about age.
  • An impacted tooth is the one that fails to erupt into proper function in the dental arch within the expected time.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incisors and B. canines are successional permanent teeth, meaning they replace their deciduous counterparts.

 

Option C: Premolars are also successional permanent teeth, erupting in place of deciduous molars.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

While, Super-added permanent teeth do not have deciduous predecessors, i.e. all permanent molars and Successional permanent teeth erupt in place of deciduous teeth i.e. incisors, canine, and premolars

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 69

choices.text: Copper sulfate

questions.text: During a quiz competition, students are challenged with questions about unique and specialized procedures. One question focuses on corneal tattooing, a procedure used to cosmetically enhance the appearance of the cornea. The students are tasked with identifying the substance commonly used in corneal tattooing. In the procedure of corneal tattooing, which substance is typically used to improve the cosmetic appearance of the cornea?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Gold chloride

 

Option A:

 

India ink is the most commonly used dye for corneal tattooing.

 

Two other methods exist: chemical dyeing with gold or platinum chloride and carbon impregnation.

 

This procedure is performed to improve the cosmetic appearance of corneal scars or leukomas, which can cause significant cosmetic issues.

 

Gold chloride, when used in corneal tattooing, imparts a color to the cornea that can resemble the natural iris, thereby improving the cosmetic appearance.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Calcium chloride - Not used. Direct contact of the salt on the skin can result in irritation or even superficial burns.

 

Option C: Copper sulfate - Not used.

 

Option D: Potassium permanganate - This is used for tattoo removal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

India ink is the most used dye for corneal tattooing. Two other methods exist: chemical dyeing with gold or platinum chloride and carbon impregnation.

 

Dyes used for skin tattooing: Indigo, cobalt, carbon, vermilion, cadmium, selenium, Prussian blue, Ultramarine blue, and Indian ink.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 92-93

choices.text: The Act now allows for the adoption of children in need of care and protection
Juveniles aged 16 to 18 involved in serious crimes can be tried as adults
The Act establishes a special provision for heinous crimes committed by children aged 14-16 years
Child Welfare Committees (CWCs) have been granted the authority to finalize adoption cases

questions.text: You are conducting a seminar for junior and senior residents. The focus is on the recent updates in juvenile law, specifically the Juvenile Justice Act-2021. Your objective is to address common misconceptions and provide clear insights into the revisions made in the Act. You pose a question to challenge the attendees’ understanding and identify any false perceptions about the Act. In the context of the recent amendments made to the Juvenile Justice Act-2021, which of the following statements does not accurately reflect the changes or current stipulations of the Act?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Child Welfare Committees (CWCs) have been granted the authority to finalize adoption cases

 

Option D:

 

Juvenile Justice Act-2021 - The Act assigns the authority to finalize adoption cases to the District Magistrate (DM) or Additional District Magistrate (ADM), not to the Child Welfare Committees. This change was made to expedite the adoption process and ensure better oversight and management.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The Act now allows for the adoption of children in need of care and protection.

 

This statement is correct. The Juvenile Justice Act-2021 has provisions for the adoption of children who are found to need care and protection. The Act streamlines the adoption process, aiming to make it more efficient and child friendly.

 

Option B: Juveniles aged 16 to 18 involved in serious crimes can be tried as adults.

 

This statement is accurate and reflects a significant aspect of the Act. The Juvenile Justice Act-2021 allows for juveniles in the age group of 16 to 18 years, who are involved in serious offenses, to be tried as adults. This provision is contingent upon the nature of the crime and the decision of the Juvenile Justice Board after a preliminary assessment.

 

Option C: The Act establishes a special provision for heinous crimes committed by children aged 14-16 years.

 

This is also correct. The Juvenile Justice Act-2021 includes provisions for children aged 14-16 years involved in heinous crimes. The treatment of such cases depends on the nature of the offense and the circumstances, emphasizing both the accountability of the juvenile and the possibility of rehabilitation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile Justice Act-2021 Key aspects include:

 

  • Adoption Provisions of children in need of care and protection.
  • Juveniles Tried as Adults: It allows for juveniles aged 16 to 18, involved in serious offenses
  • Provisions for Children Aged 14-16 Years involved in heinous crimes, balancing accountability with the potential for rehabilitation.
  • Authority in Adoption Cases is assigned to the District Magistrate or Additional District Magistrate.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 82, CARA (Central adoption Resource Authority) (https://cara.wcd.gov.in/PDF/JJ%20Amendment%20Act%20-2021_.PDF)

questions.text: During a practical examination, you're presented with a bone specimen for analysis. The examiner highlights a particular anatomical feature with an arrow and asks you to deduce the type of forensic information that can be obtained from examining this feature. In the context of forensic medicine, what type of information can be determined from the structure indicated by the arrow on the bone specimen?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sex

 

Option B:

 

The structure indicated by the arrow is the preauricular sulcus, used for sex determination.

 

Preauricular Sulcus has been described as a characteristic of the female pelvis. The pelvic portion of the anterior sacroiliac ligament is attached to it. Its prominence results from obstetrical trauma during the course of delivery which allows for differentiation between nulliparous women and males vs females who have given birth

 

Males - Not frequent, narrow, shallow Preauricular Sulcus

 

Females - More frequent, broad, deep Preauricular Sulcus

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Age determination - from the Pubic symphyseal morphology - It is the best single criterion for determining age-at death for individuals from third to fifth decade

 

Option C: Race can be estimated from skull and indices of the long bones, not from the pelvis.

 

Option D: Stature estimation is generally made from the lengths of the long bones like the femur or humerus, not pelvic bone features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sulcus is used for sex determination.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 62

questions.text:
In a practical examination for a forensics course, you are presented with a fingerprint specimen. The examiner asks you to scrutinize the print and determine the category of the fingerprint pattern based on its distinctive features.

 

 

After careful observation of the fingerprint image provided, into which of the following categories does this fingerprint pattern fall?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loop

 

Option A:

 

The loop pattern is the most prevalent fingerprint pattern in the general population. This type of pattern is characterized by ridges that enter on one side of the finger, form a curve, and then exit on the same side. Loops are subdivided into radial and ulnar loops, depending on the direction of their opening. This pattern is significant in forensic science due to its high occurrence rate, which can be a critical factor in the identification process.

 

 

Types & Percentage of fingerprint ridges –

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Arches are the simplest and least common fingerprint patterns, with ridges flowing on one side and out the other without recurving.

 

Option C: Whorl patterns, identifiable by their circular or spiral formation, are the second most common type but are less prevalent than loops.

 

Option D: Composite patterns are complex and incorporate characteristics of two or more of the basic patterns (loops, whorls, and arches), making them less common than simple loops.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dactylography (dermatoglyphics, Galton system) is the study of fingerprints as a method of identification. The loop pattern is the most prevalent (67%) fingerprint pattern in the general population.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 85

choices.text: If the hair displays a continuous medulla, it is indicative of human origin.
A hair with pigment granules distributed toward the cuticle rather than the medulla suggests animal origin.
The presence of a root that is brush-like in appearance would suggest the hair is of animal origin.
Hair with a very narrow or absent medulla is typically characteristic of animal hair.

questions.text: A forensic expert is evaluating evidence at a crime scene. Among the collected items, strands of hair are found, which could be pivotal in linking a suspect to the scene. To determine their origin, the analyst must compare their microscopic characteristics to known human and animal hair attributes. Upon microscopic examination of hair strands found at a crime scene, which feature would most likely determine if the hair is of human or animal origin?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The presence of a root that is brush-like in appearance would suggest the hair is of animal origin.

 

Option C:

 

Human hair roots typically take on a more bulbous or ribbon-like shape, while many animal hairs have a root structure that resembles a brush. This feature can be used to distinguish between human and animal hair when analyzing forensic evidence.

 

Characteristic features –

 

Human Hair - Fine, thin, cuticular scales are short, broad, not continuous, cortex-thick 4-10 times as broad as medulla; medulla-narrow; continuous, fragmented or entirely absent. Pigment-evenly distributed. Precipitin test is specific for human beings.

 

Animals Hair - Coarse, thick, cuticular scales very large, step like projection, cortex thin, continuous, and wider Medulla.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Incorrect. A continuous medulla is more commonly associated with animal hair; human hair may have a fragmented or absent medulla.

 

Option B: Incorrect. Pigment granules near the cuticle are not a primary distinguishing feature between human and animal hair.

 

Option D: Incorrect, narrow, or absent medulla is characteristic of Human Hair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human hair is fine, thin, with a narrow medulla and uniformly distributed pigment granules, while animal hair is coarser, thicker, with a broad, continuous medulla and clumped pigment near it. The hair features, including shaft diameter, root shape, and medullary index, differ significantly between humans and animals.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 95

questions.text: A body has been received for autopsy, during your duty hours, where a deceased individual is reported to have had a tattoo, yet it remains undiscovered during the preliminary external examination of the autopsy. Given the history provided by the patient's relative, the residents are tasked with deciding the next step in the forensic examination to locate the tattoo. When a tattoo reported by a relative is not visible during an initial autopsy examination, which part of the body should be dissected to potentially discover the presence of the tattoo?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph node

 

Option A:

 

In order to achieve the permanent effect, tattoo ink is injected into the dermis – the deeper layer of the skin – and stays in the skin for a lifetime. Over time, macrophages take up pigment and may transport it into the lymphatic system and lymph nodes.

 

A faded tattoo mark becomes visible by the use of ultraviolet lamp or rubbing the part and examining with magnifying lens. Infrared photography makes old tattoos readily visible. The marks are recognized even in decomposed bodies when the epidermis is removed by wiping the area with a moist paper towel or a piece of cloth.

 

If a tattoo is not visible due to external factors such as skin decomposition or damage, examining the nearby/regional lymph nodes may reveal the presence of tattoo pigment, thus confirming the history provided by the relative.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Skin - Normally, the skin would be the first place to check for a tattoo, but if the tattoo is not visible on the skin due to decomposition or other reasons, it might not be helpful.

 

Option C: Spleen and Option D: Kidney - These internal organs would not typically contain tattoo ink unless there is widespread systemic distribution, which is unusual and does not aid in identifying the location of a tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases where the skin does not reveal the tattoo, possibly due to decomposition, burns etc., lymph nodes dissection to be done for tattoo pigment as evidence.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 92

choices.text: It provides an indicator for estimating the infant's age at the time of death.
It can be a site of non-accidental injury in cases of suspected infant trauma.
It normally closes between 16 and 18 months, which can be used to assess developmental delays or abnormalities.
It is anatomically formed by the convergence of the parietal and occipital bones.

questions.text: In the context of forensic medicine, which statement concerning the posterior fontanelle is incorrect, particularly when evaluating the developmental stage of an infant during a post-mortem examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It normally closes between 16 and 18 months, which can be used to assess developmental delays or abnormalities.

 

Option C:

 

This statement is incorrect as the posterior fontanelle generally closes much earlier, usually by the age of 2 to 3 months. Delayed closure can indicate underlying developmental or health issues but expecting closure at 16-18 months is inaccurate and could lead to misjudgment in a forensic setting.

 

Suture closure in skull occurs later in females than in males

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The condition of the fontanelle can indeed help estimate an infant's developmental age at the time of death.

 

Option B: The posterior fontanelle can be examined for concealed trauma, which is essential in cases of suspected non-accidental injury.

 

Option D: The posterior fontanelle is formed at the juncture of the parietal and occipital bones, which is correct and can be confirmed during an autopsy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Age determination from skull suture closure –

 

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 79-80

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the casualty department of a medical college hospital with severe pain in his lower jaw. He reports that the pain has been gradually worsening over the past few weeks. He has no significant past medical or dental history. On examination, the casualty medical officer notes swelling and tenderness around the angle of the jaw. An X-ray of the jaw shows an impacted tooth. In forensic odontology, identifying impacted teeth can be crucial for age estimation and identity in certain cases. Which tooth is most frequently impacted and could likely be the cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lower Third Molar

 

Option D:

 

Impacted tooth is a tooth which is not able to erupt completely if there is not enough room for the teeth, or they are not aligned properly. Such trapped teeth are known as impacted teeth.

 

Most frequent teeth to impacted is Lower third Molar. Other commonly impacted teeth are upper third molar, upper canine, and Lower canine.

 

The below image shows impacted lower third molar:

 

 

All the teeth can be visualized by single X-ray by dental panoramic tomograph (orthopantogram).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: First Molar - This tooth typically erupts without impaction due to sufficient space and earlier eruption time.

Option B: Second Molar - While it can be impacted, it is far less common than the third molar.
 

Option C: Upper Third Molar - Impaction can occur, but it is less frequent than in the lower third molar.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medicolegal aspect of teeth eruption - Age Estimation

 

If, in the jaw all 3rd molars are present, then the age  is over 18 years, but their absence gives no certain idea about age.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 80

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to a primary health center for a routine health check-up. The medical officer, aware of the importance of dental development in pediatric assessments, observes the child's dentition. In the primary dentition, it is often noted that certain upper teeth appear earlier than their lower counterparts. Which upper teeth typically erupt earlier than their corresponding lower teeth?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral Incisors

 

Option B:
