As a general rule, the lower teeth erupt earlier than upper teeth in both temporary and permanent teeth.

 

The exception is temporary Lateral Incisors which erupt earlier in upper Jaw than in lower jaw.

 

Also, in general, both temporary and permanent teeth appear slightly earlier in females as compared to boys.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Central Incisors - In primary dentition, lower (6-8 months) central incisors usually erupt earlier then upper one (7-9 months).
 

Option C: Canines - The eruption of canines in the upper and lower jaws is generally around the same age (17-18 months).

 

Option D: Molars - The first (at 12-14 months) and second (2-2 years) molars in primary dentition also tend to erupt around the same age.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eruption of deciduous teeth

 

Core Concept: Age of eruption of Temporary teeth 

  • Lower central incisors - 5 to 6 months 
  • Upper central incisors - 6 to 7 months 
  • Upper lateral incisors - 7 to 8 months 
  • Lower lateral incisors - 8 to 9 months 
  • First molars - 1 year
  • Canines - 1 years
  • Second molars - 2 to 2 years

 

Easy way to remember (Rule of halves):

I (First Incisor) - 06 months

M (First Molar) - 12 months

C (Canine) - 18 months

M (second molar) - 24-30 months

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 80

questions.text: An unidentified body is brought to the district hospital for a forensic examination. The medical officer, tasked with estimating the age of the deceased, focuses on the physiological changes in the teeth. The teeth show signs of wear and other changes that are typically not seen in younger individuals. In forensic odontology, a specific method is utilized for age estimation based on the physiological changes of teeth, especially in individuals over the age of 25. Which method is commonly employed for this purpose in forensic medicine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gustafson's method

 

Option D:

 

Gustafson’s method for age determination from teeth is based on the age-related physiological changes in teeth after 25 years of age (sometimes after 21 years).

 

6 Criteria are - Attrition, Periodontosis, Secondary dentin, Cementum apposition, Root resorption and Root transparency. Most of the criteria (except attrition and periodontosis) used in this formula are useful only while examining a dead subject or skeletal remains because for examination of such changes, teeth have to be extracted from their sockets. Most reliable criteria are Root transparency.

 

The method is usually used in determining the age of the victim, when teeth are the only trace evidence collected as in cases of victims of bomb blast or air crash disasters.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Galton’s method - This is Dactylography/dermatoglyphics; the study of fingerprints as a method of identification.

 

Option B: Bertillon's method - The first scientific method of criminal identification, called bertillion system, is attributable to Alphonse Bertillon, includes- descriptive data, body marks, photographs, and body measurements such as head length, width, arm length, and other body dimensions.

 

Option C: Pearson's method - Pearson’s regression formula is used determine the stature based on long bones (first reported this in 1899). When whole skeleton is not available, but one or the other long bones are available, then regression equations are used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gustafson’s Criteria - Six age-associated parameters are studied (Mnemonic- SCRIPT):

 

Secondary dentin

 

Cementum apposition

 

Root resorption

 

AttrItion (Wearing down of incisal or occlusal surface due to mastication)

 

Periodontosis (Retraction of gum margin and loosening of tooth)

 

Transparency of root  (due to rarefaction of the dentin tissue)

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 70

questions.text: During an autopsy of an unidentified child, the forensic expert pays special attention to the dentition as part of the identification process. The body shows no distinctive features or identifying marks. The expert notes that the decedent's temporary molars have been replaced by permanent teeth. This observation is key in forensic odontology for age estimation, particularly in cases involving unidentified bodies. In dental analysis, temporary molars are usually replaced by which type of permanent teeth?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Premolars

 

Option B:

 

Temporary molars are replaced by permanent premolars. This transition is an important marker in age estimation, especially in cases involving young, unidentified individuals. The replacement typically occurs between the ages of 10 and 12 years, aiding forensic experts in estimating the age of deceased individuals where other identification means are not available.

 

 

Explanation:
 

Option A: Molars - Permanent molars do not replace primary teeth but rather emerge behind the primary dentition.
 

Option C: Canines - Primary canines are replaced by permanent canines.
 

Option D: Incisors - Primary incisors are replaced by permanent incisors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporary incisors and temporary canines are replaced by corresponding permanent incisors and permanent canines respectively. But temporary molars are replaced by permanent premolars (Please remember that Premolars are present only in permanent teeth). Permanent Molars do not replace any temporary teeth; they erupt in new sockets.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 80

questions.text: During a forensic practical examination, you are given a set of skeletal remains discovered in a remote area. As a forensic expert, your task is to estimate the age of the individual at the time of death, an important detail for the ongoing investigation. On examining the dentition, you note that the permanent second molars are fully erupted, while the third molars (wisdom teeth) are not yet visible. This stage of dental development is crucial for estimating the individual's age. Based on this observation, at what age do the permanent second molars typically erupt?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12 years

 

Explanation:

 

Age eruption of Permanent teeth

 

  • FirstMolars - 6 to 7 years
  • CentralIncisors - 7 to 8 years
  • Lateral Incisors - 8 to 9 years
  • First Premolars - 9 to 10 years
  • Second Premolars - 10 to 11 years
  • Canines - 11 to 12 years
  • Second Molars - 12 to 14 years
  • Third Molars - 17 to 25 years

 

Mnemonic: Mother Isin Pain Papa Can Make Medicine

 

Educational Objective:

 

Permanent Second Molar teeth erupts at 12-14 years

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 80

choices.text: Symphyseal height more in males

questions.text: During a forensic anthropology workshop, a group of medical students is presented with a set of unidentified skeletal remains for examination. The task is to determine various characteristics of the individual, including their gender, based on skeletal features. One of the key elements under study is the mandible. The students are asked to identify which feature of the mandible is not typically associated with a male when compared to a female. Understanding these differences is crucial in forensic anthropology for accurately identifying the sex of skeletal remains. Which of the following features is not related to the mandible of a male in comparison to females?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Angle of ramus - More obtuse

 

Option A:

 

Angle of mandible helps to know the age as well as sex.

 

It is more Obtuse in:  Children Elderly Females

 

It is less obtuse in adults and males.

 

 

General differences between male and female bones: There are some general features which help to differentiate male and female bones. These are applicable to most bones, hence no need to remember separately for each bone. These are

 

  • Size: Male bones tend are larger than female bones.
  • Thickness: Male bones are thicker and denser than female bones.
  • Length: Bones are Longer in males compared to females.
  • Texture: The texture of male bones can be rougher and more rugged due to increased muscle attachment areas.
  • Articular Surface Size: Male bones may have larger articular surfaces compared to females.
  • Bone Markings: Bony markings where muscles and ligaments attach are more prominent in males.

 

So, for individual bones, just remember the specific features, instead of general features

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Larger condyle: As a general rule it is a feature of male bone

 

Option C: Mental tubercles- As a general rule it is a feature of male bone

 

Option D: Symphyseal height more in males: As a general rule it is a feature of male bone

 

Educational objective:

 

Mnemonic: Angle of mandible is more obtuse in CEF (C for children, E for elderly, F for female)

 

The male mandible is generally larger, thicker, and square-shaped with a less obtuse angle, everted angle of the mandible, and prominent muscular markings, whereas the female mandible is smaller, thinner, rounded, with a more obtuse angle, inverted angle of the mandible, and less prominent muscular markings.

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 62

questions.text: A person is accused of committing Rape. He claims to be an adolescent. He is brought to the government hospital for age estimation to determine if he should be sent to juvenile home or an adult jail. The X-ray image of the pelvis is shown below. What is the age?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 17-18 years

 

Explanation:

 

Head, greater trochanter, and lesser trochanter are all fused with the shaft of femur (so age > 17 years)

 

 Iliac crest is not yet fused (so age < 18 years)

 

Hence, age is 17-18 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

A- appear F- Fuse

 

Ref - Reddy 33/e. Pg 78
